title: LibGuides: Clinical Nutrition: Drugs and Supplements
author: Hayley Severson; MLIS
description: Resources available regarding clinical nutrition topics
cleaned_text: Froedtert Health has implemented a new security protocol which has resulted in the degradation of on-campus access to MCW Libraries' electronic resources. Users on the Froedtert network must sign in via OpenAthens when attempting to access electronic library resources (including UpToDate, VisualDx, etc.). MCW Libraries is aware of this change and is working to provide a permanent access solution. If you have MCW credentials, please sign in via MCW employees and students when prompted. If you are a Froedtert employee, [ click here to register for an OpenAthens account](https://register.openathens.net/mcw.edu/register) or [ view more information](https://mcw.libguides.com/linking/OA-NonMCW). Online Drug Information Resources [ClinicalKey Drug Monographs](https://www.clinicalkey.com/#!/browse/drugs) by ClinicalKey, this database delivers drug monographs including dosage, administration, interactions, and adverse reactions. [Daily Med](https://dailymed.nlm.nih.gov/dailymed/index.cfm) DailyMed provides trustworthy information about marketed drugs. DailyMed is the official provider of FDA label information (package inserts). This Web site provides a standard, comprehensive, up-to-date, look-up and download resource of medication content and labeling found in medication package inserts. The National Library of Medicine (NLM) provides this as a public service and does not accept advertisements. The drug labeling information on this Web site is the most recent submitted to the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and currently in use; it may include, for example, strengthened warnings undergoing FDA review or minor editorial changes. These labels have been reformatted to make them easier to read. [Drugs and Lactation Database (LactMed)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK501922/) The LactMed® database contains information on drugs and other chemicals to which breastfeeding mothers may be exposed. It includes information on the levels of such substances in breast milk and infant blood, and the possible adverse effects in the nursing infant. Suggested therapeutic alternatives to those drugs are provided, where appropriate. All data are derived from the scientific literature and fully referenced. A peer review panel reviews the data to assure scientific validity and currency. [MedlinePlus Drug Information](https://medlineplus.gov/druginformation.html) Learn about your prescription drugs and over-the-counter medicines. Includes side effects, dosage, special precautions, and more. Online Herb and Supplement Resources [MedlinePlus Herbs and Supplement Information](https://medlineplus.gov/druginfo/herb_All.html) Browse dietary supplements and herbal remedies to learn about their effectiveness, usual dosage, and drug interactions. [National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine: Herbs at a Glance](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/herbsataglance.htm) Herbs at a Glance is a series of brief fact sheets that provides basic information about specific herbs or botanicals—common names, what the science says, potential side effects and cautions, and resources for more information. [Natural Medicines: Commercial Products](https://go.openathens.net/redirector/mcw.edu?url=https://naturalmedicines.therapeuticresearch.com/databases/commercial-products.aspx) A database of commercial dietary supplement products (over 90,000). Each product monograph includes the product's name, ingredients, effectiveness, safety, interactions, and adverse events. These monographs also feature our Natural Medicines Brand Evidence-based Rating (NMBER). NMBER is a unique clinical tool that assigns evidence-based ratings to multi-ingredient, commercially available products based on safety, effectiveness, and overall product quality. [Natural Medicines: Food, Herbs, and Supplements](https://go.openathens.net/redirector/mcw.edu?url=https://naturalmedicines.therapeuticresearch.com/databases/food,-herbs-supplements.aspx) Natural Medicines contains over 1200 monographs on natural ingredients, including vitamins, herbs, minerals, non-herbal supplements, naturally sourced chemical compounds, and foods. Each monograph provides scientific, evidence-based information on Safety, Effectiveness, and Interactions. In addition to the Professional version, each monograph is also available as a Patient Handout in English, Spanish, and French. These are designed to be given to patients and are written so they can be easily understood by a general consumer. [Office of Dietary Supplements (NIH)](http://ods.od.nih.gov/) ODS seeks to strengthen knowledge and understanding of dietary supplements by evaluating scientific information, supporting research, sharing research results, and educating the public. Its resources include publications (such as Dietary Supplements: What You Need to Know), fact sheets on a variety of specific supplement ingredients and products (such as vitamin D and multivitamin/mineral supplements), and the PubMed Dietary Supplement Subset. Informative Apps [HerbList](https://nccih.nih.gov/Health/HerbListApp) HerbList is an innovative way to deliver information about herbal safety and effects to users. The information is supported by research-based data on herbs and herbal supplements. [MCW Libraries](http://www.mcw.edu/Libraries.htm) 8701
